programmes.show_description: Mark Ronson performs on the Other Stage on the first day of Glastonbury 2015. Contains very strong language and scenes of flashing images.
6/6. Michael McIntyre returns with his National Television Award-winning Big Show, featuring Jade Thirlwall, Jack Savoretti, Tasha Ghouri and an incredible Unexpected Star of the Show.
7/8. Surprising secrets come to light at both Tender and SternTao. Contains very strong language.
3/6. Kacey comes to Michael's house to meet the prophets and is shocked by what she sees. Contains strong language.
Highlights of programmes on BBC Two.
8/15. Marketing assistant Angus guides the group on a fashion-themed hike around Harbottle. But will his cordon bleu picnic hit the spot with the picky eaters?
Hamza Yassin is on the west coast of Scotland, where hidden beneath the waves lives one of our rarest marine giants - the flapper skate.
The latest news, sport, business and weather from the BBC's Breakfast team.
5/6. Ian Hamilton and Major head to the Fife town of Cupar.
2/29. The remaining three chefs from north west England compete over mains and desserts inspired by the British film industry. Who will win, and who must go home?
3/29. It's judging day, and only one chef can go through to represent north west England. Casting director Debbie McWilliams helps decide the winner from the two remaining chefs.
2/10. Three enthusiasts in South Africa investigate the honey badger's fearsome reputation as nature's most aggressive and pugnacious fighter.
Classic Hitchcock suspense drama in which a couple investigate the mysterious disappearance of an elderly lady on a train. [1938]
Espionage thriller based on the true story of an intelligence officer who plans an elaborate hoax to fool the Nazis into thinking the Allies are about to invade Greece, not Sicily. [1956]
5/5. How dramatic twists in Earth's story enabled humans to go from being part of nature to controlling it, and what can be learnt from this tale before it's too late.
22/60. Paul Martin is at Glemham Hall in the Suffolk countryside, where David Fletcher discovers some Lovejoy scripts and Jonathan Pratt spots some bobbing Beatles dolls.
Wealthy Emma Woodhouse needs a new companion when her beloved governess Miss Taylor gets married. She settles on Harriet Smith, and becomes determined to make a match for her. [2020]
1/12. Lucy and Adam's big move to their dream farm in Scotland hangs in the balance.
1/6. The Big Cats 24/7 team returns to the Okavango Delta. With bigger cubs to feed, the lions hunt around the clock. New female leopard Lediba has cubs, and cheetah Pobe is back.
A teenager is the prime suspect when a 12-year-old boy is fatally stabbed in a park. Contains scenes which some viewers may find upsetting.
Renowned Irish jazz singer and violinist Suzanne Savage collaborates with prolific music producer and fiddle player Daithí Ó Drónaí.
Featuring American Grammy Award winner Rhiannon Giddens, Italian multi-instrumentalist Francesco Turrisi and renowned Connemara sean-nós singer Róisín Elsafty.
Mark Carruthers looks at the political developments of the week and questions policymakers on the key issues.
It's winter, and boats need to be repaired, livestock moved and nesting boxes checked.
A rural burglary backfires when the victims turn on the thieves - for their entertainment! Contains very strong language, some violence and upsetting scenes. [2022]
7/10. Jack gets into a bar fight and must decide whether to involve Nikki and the Bowman team. Contains some strong language, some violence and some upsetting scenes.
8/10. The Bowman team work tirelessly to save Jack from a life-threatening predicament. Contains some strong language and some upsetting scenes.
Fiona Bruce presents an hour of debate from Birmingham. On the panel, Lisa Nandy MP, Alicia Kearns MP, Jess Brown-Fuller MP, Tom Kerridge and Esther Krakue.
Highlights of programmes on BBC Two.
Take your seat as the curtain opens on a special episode to celebrate 50 years of British theatre's coveted awards.
5/14. Co-founder and CEO of Refy Beauty, Jenna Meek, returns to the Den.
Kelly Cates presents highlights of the day's four Premier League games: Arsenal v Chelsea, Brighton v Nottingham Forest, Fulham v Tottenham and Manchester United v Crystal Palace.
Twenty-four hours a day, the latest national and international stories as they break.
The big political issues of the day.
6/30. Game show in which players score points by answering questions correctly while avoiding the Impossible answers.
10/45. Jason Manford hosts the quiz where it's not just about finding the right answer, it's finding the best answer that counts.
16/25. Susan Calman hosts the quiz show where being in control is everything. Who will emerge as the Boss and walk away with the cash?
16/20. Antiques dealers Melissa Drabble, Lucy Ryder Richardson and Jon Swanston are in Carpentras to find two hidden treasures each to sell online for the most profit.
The quiet village of Ravenglass in the Lake District's National Park played a strategic role in the Roman empire, as archaeologist Ben Robinson finds out.
6/8. The team explores the coastal waters of the Indian Ocean to discover what happens when this powerful ocean collides with the edge of a continent.
19/40. Today, Flog It! comes from Newby Hall, North Yorkshire. Mark Stacey comes across two unusual tie and stick pins, and Clare Rawle enthuses about a large collection of toy cars.

programmes.show_name: New: Richard Osman's House of Games
programmes.show_description: 81/100. Josh Jones, Sarah Keyworth, Melvin Odoom and Kimberly Wyatt test their general knowledge.
6/20. Vernon Kay and unreliable tour guide Paul Gorton test Nitin Ganatra, Rev Kate Bottley and Gladiator Apollo on their knowledge of the UK. Today's tour is of Derry/Londonderry.
We go behind the mass protests in Nepal that toppled the government. Eyewitness accounts reveal how unarmed demonstrators were killed as authorities lost control of the crowds.
6/6. Paul heads to the River Ayr for this Grand Tour. Starting on Hareshaw Hill, he uncovers a legacy of mineral wealth and religious conflict before reaching the Clyde coast.
24/31. Clive Myrie hosts the classic quiz where contenders take on the famous black chair. Subjects include Jimi Hendrix, the operas of Giacomo Puccini and Wilfred Owen.
30/37. Two teams return to play a second quarter-final. Having both lost their first, they need to win this one to stay in the competition. Amol Rajan asks the questions.
2/3. What happens when pedestrians are killed by driverless cars, and who is to blame? Contains some strong language and some upsetting scenes.
Ríoghnach Connolly, Sidiki Dembélé and Shunya meet for a musical collaboration that fuses Irish and West African traditions.
Insights and global interviews on the news stories of the day. With Victoria Derbyshire.   Followed by Weather.
4/6. Kacey comes round to help bury the jars and asks Michael about the hoarded boxes. Contains some strong language.
1/16. Sandi Toksvig hosts as QI goes voyaging with Nabil Abdulrashid, Joe Lycett, Lou Sanders and Alan Davies. Contains some strong language.
